page.title: 13VINEYARD AT COLN ROGERS.
page.content: From old maps going back to Roman times it appears that a site on the eastern banks of the Coln by Swain's Bridge was favoured in times gone by as a suitable situation for a vineyard. In 1979 it was decided to plant the one-acre site once again with vines. The grapes produced are mostly white, although some vines bearing red grapes were included. In a good year the quantity of wine produced amounts to 4000-5000 bottles, most of which are sold on a commercial basis under the name of "Cotes du Coln". The success of this venture is very dependent on the weather, and in the poor summer of l985 it is doubtful if much wine was produced. On such a small scale it is not commercially viable to instal a plant for processing the grapes, which are sent to the Forest of Dean for this purpose
